Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Hierarchical Feature Learning by Heterogeneous Networks with Application to Face Verification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning good features is a key to computer vision problems such as recognizing human faces, and understanding scenes. Many computer vision researchers learn features by providing a semantic label for each image in a large database, limiting the amount of information per image to a few bits. Others learn features by identifying common patterns found in images such as lines, blobs, and more complicated shapes, but ignoring semantic information. This project develops algorithms to learn features that are common in images and also predict the semantics of images at various spatial scales using a new type of deep neural network called Heterogeneous Networks. The developed algorithms allow the incorporation of semantic information at intermediate layers. The algorithms developed can not only change how features are learned but also indicate how to scale feature learning to giant datasets of millions of images. The research team addresses challenging problems in human face verification using NCSA's petascale supercomputer, Blue Waters, and two large scale (millions of images) image data sets.

The research of this projected is integrated with both undergraduate and graduate education. The results obtained from this project are applicable to a wide range of applications in computer vision and pattern recognition. The research team plans to release algorithms and face data sets collected in this project to research communities once they are finished.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deep learning is a family of machine methods that have in recent years let to breakthrough in multiple areas of artificial intelligence. The project has the goal of improving the deep learning methods for computer vision in several aspects: improve the scalability of the computation to allow model learning from larger amount of  training data; improve the interpretability of deep learning models to enhance the semantic meaning of individual neurons to better understand the mechanism. improve the performance on computer vision tasks including face and generic object recognition and localization;

The main output of this project were threefold:  First, on the computational aspect, we developed deep learning training and inference software using distributed GPU machines. The infrastructure allows us to train deep learning models several times faster than previous approaches, and also to train larger models with increased performance.  Second, we were motivated by the feedback attention mechanism of human visual cortex and developed a new model training method which allows neuron activations to be controlled by both top-down and bottom-up signals. Object recognition models trained with this method have better interpretable neurons as shown in visualization and analysis. Third, we made various improvements to existing deep learning methods for various applications including image/video object detection (participated in ILSVRC 2015 VID challenge and ranked 3rd place),  facial expression analysis, learning from network-structured data.  Our developed algorithms and source codes are available on the research group website.

The project has supported or partially supported 5 Ph.D dissertation. The project also provides materials for two courses at UIUC. The results of this project were published on leading computer vision and machine learning conferences and journals.
